clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Timing of a Post-exercise Oral Glucose Tolerance Test on Glycaemic Control.
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Timing of a Post-exercise Oral Glucose Tolerance Test on Glycaemic Control.

brief_summary.textblock:
Postprandial glycaemic control is an important risk factor for the development of type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease and all-cause mortality.
Previous research has demonstrated that exercise performed in the postprandial state paradoxically results in a deterioration in glucose tolerance in the immediate post-exercise period (Gonzalez et a. 2013; Gonzalez and Stevenson 2013). This study aims to assess the timecourse of this post-exercise effect.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Basic Science

primary_outcome.measure: Postprandial glucose concentration area under the curve
primary_outcome.description: Blood glucose concentrations will be sampled every 15 min following an oral glucose tolerance test.

secondary_outcome.measure: Postprandial insulin concentration area under the curve
secondary_outcome.description: Insulin concentrations will be determine every 15 min following an oral glucose tolerance test.

arm_group.description: Breakfast followed by a rest period prior to OGTT.
Breakfast followed by exercise and an immediate OGTT
Breakfast followed by exercise and a delayed (1 h) OGTT.

intervention.description: Exercise at 55% of maximum power output for 30 min.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Normal weight (18-25 kg/m2)
- Physically active (>or= 3 times per week)
- Male
Exclusion Criteria:
- Contraindications to exercise
- Food intolerances
- Food allergies
